Google Cloud includes services like Vertex AI and the Gemini family of models.
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) combines document retrieval with large language models to answer questions using private data.
Using services such as Cloud Run and Cloud SQL can help optimise cost for AI applications.

Tunnel Vision Module: CS1813 Assessment block code: Task 5 Assignment Title: Tunnel Vision Robot Task number: 5 Name: Ammad Raza ID: 2431974 Tutor: Alessandro Pandini Group: A12   b) Requirement Speciﬁcations 1. Core Functionalities  The program should: • Start execution when the ‘Y’ button is pressed. • Set the SwiftBots’s underlights to red and move forward at a slow speed. • Capture images at r

ove forward at a slow speed. • Capture images at regular intervals while moving. • Process images to determine light intensity. • Detect tunnel entry and exit using charges in light intensity. • Compute the distance travelled using calibration data. 
• Stop if an obstacle is detected within 40 cm, take a photo of the obstacle, notify the suer, and terminate execution. • Allow manual termination by

terminate execution. • Allow manual termination by pressing the ‘X’ button. • At termination, ask the user if they want to display the execution.log. • Save the log to a test ﬁle and display its ﬁle path to the user.  2. Additional Functionalities  • Auto-Calibration Mode: Automates-distance calibration instead of requiring manual input. • Live Status Updates: Displays real-time tunnel detection a

tus Updates: Displays real-time tunnel detection and light intensity data. • Data logging for performance Tracking: Storers multiple execution logs for future analysis. • Enhanced Error Handling: Provides informative feedback for unexpected input or sensor failures.    c) Algorithm Design

Cover Page • Module and Assessment Block Codes and Titles: CS1704 Software Engineering – Assessment 2 • Assignment Title: Tunnel Vision • Robot Task Number and Title: Task 5: Tunnel Vision • My Name: Ammad Raza • My ID: 24321974 • Tutor: Alessandro Pandini • Group Name: Group A 12            
Required Functionalities: 1. Tunnel Measurement Using Camera Input: I developed the program so that the Sw

mera Input: I developed the program so that the SwiftBot continuously captures grayscale images and computes the average light intensity from each image. A baseline intensity is computed from images taken outside the tunnels, which is then used to determine when the robot enters and exits a tunnel. 2. Tunnel Detection and Distance Measurement: My program detects tunnel entry when the average light

rogram detects tunnel entry when the average light intensity drops below a threshold (baseline × 0.5) and detects tunnel exit when it rises above that threshold. I calculate the distance traveled using a calibrated conversion factor (CALIBRATION_FACTOR) that transforms time intervals (in milliseconds) into centimeters. 3. Dynamic Baseline Updating: After the SwiftBot exits tunnels 1 and 2, the pro

After the SwiftBot exits tunnels 1 and 2, the program recalculates a new baseline intensity to adapt to any changes in ambient lighting. However, after the final (third) tunnel exit, rather than recalculating the baseline, the program activates red underlights as an indication that the measurement process is complete. 4. Obstacle Detection: The program continuously monitors for obstacles using th

ogram continuously monitors for obstacles using the ultrasound sensor. If an obstacle is detected within 40 cm, the SwiftBot stops, captures a photo of the obstacle, displays the log, turns on red under lights and immediately terminates the program by calling System.exit(5). 5. User-Controlled Termination: The measurement starts when I press the ‘Y’ button on the SwiftBot. If at any point I press

’ button on the SwiftBot. If at any point I press the ‘X’ button, the program immediately displays the log and terminates using System.exit(5). 6. Logging: I implemented detailed logging to record all key events, including baseline intensity measurements, tunnel entries and exits (with corresponding tunnel lengths and average intensities), gap distances between tunnels, total distance traveled, ex

ances between tunnels, total distance traveled, execution duration, and obstacle details (if any). I updated the logger to use an anonymous formatter that outputs only the log level and message, omitting date and time for a cleaner display. The log is automatically displayed and written to a text file upon termination. 7. Command-Line Interface (CLI): I provided a simple text-based interface that

I): I provided a simple text-based interface that guides me through starting the measurement, manually stopping it if needed, and exiting the program. The log is automatically displayed and saved without additional user input. Additional Functionalities: • Modular Design with Inheritance: To enhance code organization and demonstrate my understanding of object-oriented programming, I refactored the

g of object-oriented programming, I refactored the code using inheritance. I created an abstract base class, TunnelVisionBase, which encapsulates common image processing functions such as computing the average and baseline intensities. The main class, SwiftBotTunnelVision, extends this base class and implements the measurement loop, obstacle handling, and CLI functionality. This design reduces cod

ng, and CLI functionality. This design reduces code duplication and improves maintainability. • Immediate Termination: 
I replaced the earlier termination flag mechanism with immediate termination via System.exit(5). Now, whenever I press the ‘X’ button or an obstacle is detected, the program immediately displays the log and terminates, ensuring a swift response to critical events. • Automatic Log

swift response to critical events. • Automatic Log Display: Instead of prompting me to choose whether to display the log, the program now always displays the log on screen and writes it to a file. This simplifies the user interaction and ensures that all execution details are communicated. • Cleaner Log Output: I modified the logging setup to use an anonymous formatter that excludes date and time

n anonymous formatter that excludes date and time stamps. This results in a cleaner log that focuses solely on the messages and severity levels.    Changes to the Algorithm and User Interface Design In my initial design (as outlined in Assignment 2), I proposed that the SwiftBot’s underlights would be activated at the start of the measurement process. Based on testing and feedback, I made the foll

ss. Based on testing and feedback, I made the following changes: • Underlights Control: I now ensure that the underlights remain off during normal measurement and are activated in red only when an obstacle is detected or after the final tunnel exit. This change reserves the red signal for critical situations and avoids unnecessary distractions during the measurement process. • Termination Handling

ng the measurement process. • Termination Handling: Initially, I used a termination flag to allow for graceful shutdown. I have now replaced that mechanism with immediate termination using System.exit(5) when the ‘X’ button is pressed, or an obstacle is detected. Before termination, however, the program automatically displays and writes the log. • Use of Inheritance: To better organize the code an

Use of Inheritance: To better organize the code and improve its modularity, I refactored the program using an abstract base class (TunnelVisionBase). This class handles common image processing tasks, and the main class (SwiftBotTunnelVision) extends it to implement the specific measurement logic. This design approach was not part of my original plan and adds significant value in terms of code qual

n and adds significant value in terms of code quality and maintainability. • CLI Refinements: I simplified the user interaction by removing the prompt that required me to press ‘Y’ to display the log. The log is now automatically displayed and saved to a file, streamlining the termination process.  
    Planning and Monitoring Progress Functionality  Test Input / Condition  Expected Output / Behav

y  Test Input / Condition  Expected Output / Behavior  Observed Output / Behavior  Pass/Fail  Comments  Baseline Intensity Computation  Place SwiftBot outside tunnels; start the program.  The program computes the baseline intensity from 5 images and displays the computed value.  Baseline intensity is computed and displayed correctly.  Pass  Baseline values are consistent with ambient lighting.  Tu

e values are consistent with ambient lighting.  Tunnel Entry Detection  SwiftBot enters a tunnel with lower light intensity.  Tunnel entry is detected when average intensity falls below (baseline × 0.5), and any gap is recorded.  Tunnel entry is detected and gap is recorded correctly.  Pass Works as expected under test conditions.  Tunnel Exit & Baseline Update  SwiftBot exits a tunnel and light i

seline Update  SwiftBot exits a tunnel and light intensity returns to baseline.  For tunnels 1 and 2, tunnel exit is detected and a new baseline is computed and displayed; for tunnel 3, red underlights are activated and log is displayed.  Tunnel exits are detected correctly; new baseline for tunnels 1 & 2; final tunnel triggers underlights and log display.  Pass Final tunnel behaviour is as expect

display.  Pass Final tunnel behaviour is as expected.  Obstacle Detection  Place an obstacle within 40 cm of SwiftBot’s path.  The SwiftBot stops, captures an image of the obstacle, displays the log, and immediately terminates the program.  Obstacle is detected; photo captured; log displayed; program terminates.  Pass Threshold confirmed through calibration tests.  User Termination (Button X)  Pre

libration tests.  User Termination (Button X)  Press the ‘X’ button during measurement.  The program immediately displays the log and terminates via System.exit(5).  Immediate termination with log display.  Pass Immediate termination works correctly.  Log Display  After measurement, the log should display automatically.  The log details are automatically output on screen and written to a file usin

ically output on screen and written to a file using a custom formatter (without date/time).  Log displayed and file written correctly.  Pass Log output is clear and well-formatted.  
My Progress Summary: • Initial Planning: I began by developing a comprehensive requirements specification and an initial algorithm design (as documented in Assignment 2). I also created a preliminary project timeline

2). I also created a preliminary project timeline outlining key milestones, including tunnel detection, image processing, and obstacle handling. • Weekly Progress Log: • Week 1: I focused on requirements analysis and the initial design. I set up my development environment and performed basic tests on the SwiftBot’s camera and sensor functionalities. • Week 2: I implemented the core image processin

. • Week 2: I implemented the core image processing functions to compute baseline and average light intensity. I also developed the initial tunnel detection logic based on these intensity values. • Week 3: I integrated the movement commands with the calibration factor, ensuring that the distance measurement was accurate. I implemented obstacle detection and photo capture functionality. • Week 4: I

ction and photo capture functionality. • Week 4: I refined the user interface (CLI) and enhanced the logging and termination processes. I iteratively tested and calibrated the system, adjusting threshold values and refining the dynamic baseline updates. • Challenges Faced and How I Overcame Them: • Calibration Issues: I faced challenges in accurately mapping the SwiftBot’s speed units to physical

ly mapping the SwiftBot’s speed units to physical distance. To overcome this, I conducted multiple calibration tests and adjusted the calibration factor based on empirical data. • Sensor Variability: The ultrasound sensor readings were inconsistent under different conditions. I implemented error handling and fine-tuned the OBSTACLE_DISTANCE_THRESHOLD after several rounds of testing. • UI Interacti

LD after several rounds of testing. • UI Interaction: Ensuring smooth CLI interactions was challenging. I revised the termination and log display logic to ensure that user input was correctly processed, and I avoided closing the input stream prematurely. • Monitoring and Adjustments: I maintained a weekly progress log and used a Gantt chart to track my tasks and milestones. Regular testing session

k my tasks and milestones. Regular testing sessions helped me identify issues early, and I made incremental improvements to the algorithm and UI based on the test results and feedback. Overall, my careful planning, continuous monitoring, and iterative testing were critical in successfully completing this task. 
1. Underlights Behavior: • In the Report: The design specified that as soon as the prog

ort: The design specified that as soon as the program starts (when button Y is pressed), the SwiftBot’s underlights should be set to red. • In My Code: I disable the underlights at the start so they remain off during measurement. They are only activated in red either when an obstacle is detected or after the final tunnel exit. This change was made to improve feedback and to reserve the red signal

to improve feedback and to reserve the red signal for critical events. 2. Dynamic Baseline Updating: • In the Report: The original design mentioned computing a baseline intensity from images taken outside the tunnels but did not explicitly state that the baseline should be updated after each tunnel. • In My Code: I implemented dynamic baseline recalibration after exiting tunnels 1 and 2. For the f

libration after exiting tunnels 1 and 2. For the final (third) tunnel, instead of computing a new baseline, I activate the red underlights. This addition enhances adaptability to varying lighting conditions. 3. User Interface (CLI) Messages: • In the Report: The proposed UI design included a startup screen with clear instructions (e.g., “Press ‘Y’ to Start” and a status screen showing real-time li

to Start” and a status screen showing real-time light intensity, tunnel detection messages, etc.). • In My Code: While I adhere to a command-line interface that guides the user through starting, terminating, and log display, the exact messages and formatting differ slightly. My code outputs messages about baseline intensity updates, tunnel entry/exit, and log prompts that may not exactly match the

it, and log prompts that may not exactly match the original mock-ups but still provide clear, real-time feedback. 4. Calibration and Distance Calculation: • In the Report: The specification required that the distance be computed using calibration data (since the speed units are ambiguous). • In My Code: I implement a calibration factor (CALIBRATION_FACTOR = 0.01) to convert time intervals into dis

_FACTOR = 0.01) to convert time intervals into distance. Although this approach is consistent with the requirement, the actual numerical value may differ from what was initially assumed in the design phase. int rgb = img.getRGB(x, y);                 int red = (rgb >> 16) & 0xFF;                 sum += red;             }         }         return (double) sum / numPixels;     } 
         protected double computeBaselineIntensity() {         int sampleCount = 5;         double sum = 0.0;         try {             for (int i = 0; i < sampleCount; i++) {                 Thread.sleep(IMAGE

leCount; i++) {                 Thread.sleep(IMAGE_INTERVAL);                 BufferedImage img = swiftBot.takeGrayscaleStill(ImageSize.SQUARE_720x720);                 double intensity = computeAverageIntensity(img);                 sum += intensity;             }         } catch (InterruptedException ie) {             System.out.println("Interrupted during baseline computation.");             lo

ted during baseline computation.");             logger.warning("Interrupted during baseline computation.");         }         double newBaseline = sum / sampleCount;         System.out.println("Computed baseline intensity: " + newBaseline);         logger.info("Computed baseline intensity: " + newBaseline);         return newBaseline;     } }   package myswiftbot;  import swiftbot.*; import java.a

kage myswiftbot;  import swiftbot.*; import java.awt.image.BufferedImage; import java.io.File; import java.io.FileWriter; import java.io.IOException; 
import java.util.ArrayList; import java.util.Scanner; import java.util.logging.*; import javax.imageio.ImageIO;  public class SwiftBotTunnelVision extends TunnelVisionBase {      // --- Configuration constants ---     private static final double TUN

constants ---     private static final double TUNNEL_ENTRY_THRESHOLD_RATIO = 0.5; // tunnel entry threshold     private static final double TUNNEL_EXIT_THRESHOLD_RATIO = 0.5;  // tunnel exit threshold     private static final int OBSTACLE_DISTANCE_THRESHOLD = 40;        // cm     private static final int EXPECTED_TUNNELS = 3;      // --- Instance state specific to this class ---     private boole

state specific to this class ---     private boolean startPressed = false;     private boolean obstacleDetected = false;     private String obstaclePhotoPath = null;          private ArrayList<Double> tunnelLengths = new ArrayList<>();     private ArrayList<Double> tunnelAverageIntensities = new ArrayList<>();     private ArrayList<Double> gapDistances = new ArrayList<>();     private double total

ntTimeMillis();         runMeasurementLoop();         measurementEndTime = System.currentTimeMillis();                  // Stop the SwiftBot.         swiftBot.stopMove();

    private void handleObstacle() {         obstacleDetected = true;         swiftBot.sto

obstacleDetected = true;         swiftBot.stopMove();         swiftBot.fillUnderlights(new int[]{255, 0, 0});         try {             BufferedImage obstacleImg = swiftBot.takeStill(ImageSize.SQUARE_720x720);             String filename = "ObstaclePhoto.png";             File file = new File(filename);             ImageIO.write(obstacleImg, "png", file);             obstaclePhotoPath = file.

Terminating measurement.");                  // Display the log file before exiting.         displayAndWriteLog();                  System.exit(5);     }          private void displayAndWriteLog() {

Hazardous materials and substance control policy
The carriage of certain hazardous materials like aerosols, fireworks and inflammable liquids aboard the aircra

ireworks and inflammable liquids aboard the aircraft is forbidden. Personal motorised vehicles such as
hoverboards, mini-Segways and smart or self-balancing wheels, are also forbidden on our flights as they contain large lithium batteries. For safety reasons, we can’t accept
these as part of checked-in baggage or as hand luggage. If you do not understand this restriction, further information may b

rstand this restriction, further information may be obtained from your airline.
The United Arab Emirates (UAE) has a very strict, zero-tolerance, anti-drugs policy. All airports within the UAE conduct thorough searches using highly
sensitive equipment. Possession of any amounts of illegal drugs by travellers entering or transiting the UAE will be subject to punishment.
Emirates cabin baggage allow

ubject to punishment.
Emirates cabin baggage allowances
Economy Class:
One piece of carry-on baggage is permitted with maximum dimensions: 55 x 38 x 22cm (22 x 15 x 8 inches) and maximum weight: 7kg (15lb).
Note: If you’re boarding in India, your carry-on baggage may not exceed 115cm or 45.3 inches (length + width + height). If your itinerary originates from Brazil, you’re
allowed a carry-on weigh

nates from Brazil, you’re
allowed a carry-on weighing 10kg (22lb).
Premium Economy:
One piece of carry-on baggage is permitted with maximum dimensions: 55 x 38 x 22cm (22 x 15 x 8 inches) and maximum weight: 10kg (22lb).
Note: If you're boarding in India, your carry-on baggage may not exceed 115cm or 45.3 inches (length + width + height).
First Class and Business Class:
Two pieces of carry-on bagg

ss and Business Class:
Two pieces of carry-on baggage permitted: one briefcase plus either one handbag or one garment bag. The briefcase may not exceed 45 x 35 x 20cm (18 x 14 x 8 inches);
the handbag may not exceed 55 x 38 x 22cm (22 x 15 x 8 inches); the garment bag can be no more than 20cm (8 inches) thick when folded. The weight of each piece must
not exceed 7kg (15lb). The total combined weig

ust
not exceed 7kg (15lb). The total combined weight of both pieces may not be more than 14kg (30lb).
Infants in all cabin classes are permitted one checked-in bag that may not exceed 55 x 38 x 22 cm (22 x 15 x 8 inches) in size and 23kg (50lb) where the piece concept
applies, or 10kg (22lb) where the weight concept applies. In addition, customers travelling with infants (and without a child seat)

travelling with infants (and without a child seat) are permitted to bring one carry-cot or one
fully collapsible stroller into the cabin if there is room. If there is no space for these items in the cabin, they will have to be checked. However, if checked, they will not count
against your baggage allowance.
Emirates checked baggage notification
Checked baggage allowances vary by fare type and clas

cked baggage allowances vary by fare type and class of travel. Check your baggage allowance, however please note that any individual item weighing more than 32kg
cannot be accepted, for health and safety reasons.
